abstract.text: The decay B 0 → ψð2SÞK þ π − is analyzed using 3 fb −1 of pp collision data collected with the LHCb detector.

A model-independent description of the ψð2SÞπ mass spectrum is obtained, using as input the Kπ mass spectrum and angular distribution derived directly from data, without requiring a theoretical description of resonance shapes or their interference.
The hypothesis that the ψð2SÞπ mass spectrum can be described in terms of Kπ reflections alone is rejected with more than 8σ significance.
This provides confirmation, in a model-independent way, of the need for an additional resonant component in the mass region of the Zð4430Þ − exotic state.

Almost all known mesons and baryons can be described in the quark model with combinations of two or three quarks, although the existence of higher multiplicity configurations, as well as additional gluonic components, is, in principle, not excluded [1].

body_text.text: II.
LHCb DETECTOR
The LHCb detector [26,27] is a single-arm forward spectrometer covering the pseudorapidity range 2 < η < 5, designed for the study of particles containing b or c quarks.
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: The detector includes a high-precision tracking system consisting of a silicon-strip vertex detector surrounding the pp interaction region [28], a large-area silicon-strip detector located upstream of a dipole magnet with a bending power of about 4 Tm, and three stations of silicon-strip detectors and straw drift tubes [29] placed downstream of the magnet.
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: The tracking system provides a measurement of momentum, p, of charged particles with a relative uncertainty that varies from 0.5% at low momentum to 1.0% at 200 GeV=c.
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: The minimum distance of a track to a primary vertex, the impact parameter, is measured with a resolution of ð15 þ 29=p T Þ μm, where p T is the component of the momentum transverse to the beam, in GeV=c.
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: Different types of charged hadrons are distinguished using information from two ring-imaging Cherenkov detectors [30].
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: Photons, electrons, and hadrons are identified by a calorimeter system consisting of scintillating-pad and preshower detectors, an electromagnetic calorimeter, and a hadronic calorimeter.
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: Muons are identified by a system composed of alternating layers of iron and multiwire proportional chambers [31].
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: The online event selection is performed by a trigger [32], which consists of a hardware stage, based on information from the calorimeter and muon systems, followed by a software stage, which applies a full event reconstruction.
body_text.section: II. LHCb DETECTOR

body_text.text: VIII.
STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT
The fact that the m ψð2SÞπ spectrum cannot be explained as a reflection of the angular structure of the Kπ system has been illustrated qualitatively.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: In this section, the disagreement is quantified via a hypothesis-testing procedure using a likelihood-ratio estimator.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: The compatibility between the expected m ψð2SÞπ distribution, accounting for the reflections of the Kπ angular structure, and that observed experimentally is tested for the three l max assignments described in the previous section, with three sets of about 1000 pseudoexperiments each.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: For each pseudoexperiment, data and simulated samples involved in the analysis chain are reproduced as pseudosamples, generated at the same statistical level as in the real case.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: The signal candidate pseudosamples are extracted from a ðm Kπ ; cos θ K Ã0 ; cos θ ψð2SÞ ; Δϕ Kπ;μμ Þ distribution obtained by an independent EvtGen [35] phase-space sample of B 0 → ψð2SÞK þ π − events.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: The distribution is generated, for each of the three l max cases previously discussed, in order to reproduce the (m Kπ ,cos θ K Ã0 ) behavior.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: The background pseudosamples are simulated according to the ðm Kπ ; cos θ K Ã0 ; cos θ ψð2SÞ ; Δϕ Kπ;μμ Þ distribution of the candidates in the B 0 invariant mass sidebands.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: Finally, to mimic the calculation of the efficiency correction factors, two additional samples are generated by extracting events from two distributions, in the same 4D space, obtained from the simulation with full detector effects, before and after the application of the analysis chain.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: The sum of the signal and background samples is then subject to background subtraction and efficiency correction, exactly as for the real data, and moments are calculated.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: In the pseudoexperiments, events are simulated with equal amounts of each ψð2SÞ polarization state.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: Effects related to ψð2SÞ polarization are only included in the pseudosample via their correlation with the Kπ mass and cos θ K Ã0 distributions, which are derived from the data.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: It has been checked that this does not significantly influence the results although the validity of such approximate treatment of ψð2SÞ polarization is, in general, analysis dependent and not necessarily appropriate in other experimental situations.

body_text.text: By including moments up to l max ¼ 30, most of the features of the m ψð2SÞπ spectrum in data are well described, as can be seen in Fig. 11.

body_text.text: An exotic state in the ψð2SÞπ system would give contributions to all Kπ Legendre polynomial moments, whereas the conventional Kπ resonances contribute only to moments corresponding to their spin and their interferences.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: If, for instance, the B 0 → ψð2SÞK þ π − decay proceeds through S, P, and D Kπ resonances, then only moments with l max ≤ 4 would exhibit significant activity.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: Therefore, activity in moments of order l max > 4 would suggest the presence of other resonant states contributing to the decay.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: Lower-order Kπ Legendre polynomial moments, determined from data and used to build the prediction, although strongly dominated by the conventional Kπ resonances, could also contain a contribution from the exotic state.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: As a consequence, a relatively small ψð2SÞπ resonant contribution could be accommodated by the Monte Carlo prediction.
body_text.section: VIII. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT

body_text.text: Conversely, a significant disagreement would imply that the ψð2SÞπ invariant mass spectrum cannot be explained as a reflection of the activity of known resonances in the Kπ system and would therefore constitute strong evidence for the presence of exotic states in the decay

body_text.text: IX.
SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS
A satisfactory description of the ψð2SÞπ mass spectrum in the decay B 0 → ψð2SÞK þ π − cannot be obtained solely from the reflections of the angular structure of the Kπ system.
body_text.section: IX. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: In particular, a clear peaking structure in the 4430 MeV=c 2 mass region remains unexplained.
body_text.section: IX. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Through a hypothesis-testing procedure based on the likelihood-ratio estimator, compatibility between the data and predictions taking into account the reflections of Kπ states up to spin 3, is excluded with a significance exceeding 8σ.
body_text.section: IX. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The most plausible configuration, which allows Kπ states with spin values depending on the Kπ mass, is excluded with a significance of more than 15σ.
body_text.section: IX. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: This work represents an alternative and modelindependent confirmation of the existence of a ψð2SÞπ resonance in the same mass region in which previous model-dependent amplitude analyses have found signals [9,11,12].
